results.content: The Complete Angular & NestJS Course is my first course with Antonio Papa and I must say I am satisfied beyond expectations. The course is really fascinating because it explains exactly what I want to know without going round and round. The course is structured in the form of short tutorials in three areas that relate to my field of practice but I wanted to understand in a practical way how they work and the course gave me exactly what I wanted to know. Well done! I am definitely considering purchasing additional courses from Antonio Papa.
results.content_html: The Complete Angular & NestJS Course is my first course with Antonio Papa and I must say I am satisfied beyond expectations. The course is really fascinating because it explains exactly what I want to know without going round and round. The course is structured in the form of short tutorials in three areas that relate to my field of practice but I wanted to understand in a practical way how they work and the course gave me exactly what I wanted to know. Well done! I am definitely considering purchasing additional courses from Antonio Papa.

results.content:
Now I have not finished the course, but have gone through some of the Angular in hopes of using this for new hires. 

I found the general final contents to be good, but for beginners some of these units need to be expanded. A few of the issues I saw are:

1. States Angular 10 in description, this is already a year old as 12 is now out. The setup instructions do install just the latest CLI, so I guess when running the latest will always be installed, but may have issues if there are combability issues.

2. Bootstrap is heavily used, but not mentioned as a dependency or explained. It is usually just copy/pasted for examples.

3. Further explanation is missing for Angular concepts, we jump in, install the CLI and start creating components. But what is a component? We seem to randomly delete spec files (I get testing is outside the scope, but we can just leave these files alone). We setup routes and use router-outlet, but why are we doing this? We add things to a module, but what is a module?
results.content_html:
Now I have not finished the course, but have gone through some of the Angular in hopes of using this for new hires.

I found the general final contents to be good, but for beginners some of these units need to be expanded. A few of the issues I saw are:

1. States Angular 10 in description, this is already a year old as 12 is now out. The setup instructions do install just the latest CLI, so I guess when running the latest will always be installed, but may have issues if there are combability issues.

2. Bootstrap is heavily used, but not mentioned as a dependency or explained. It is usually just copy/pasted for examples.

3. Further explanation is missing for Angular concepts, we jump in, install the CLI and start creating components. But what is a component? We seem to randomly delete spec files (I get testing is outside the scope, but we can just leave these files alone). We setup routes and use router-outlet, but why are we doing this? We add things to a module, but what is a module?

results.content: This is an excellent course with just the right pace and information that I was looking for.

results.content: Very clear and concise course, so far.

results.content:
This course does not delve into one technology very profoundly. Rather it will teach me what kind of knowledge I need when creating a web service using Angular and NestJS, broadly and with a sense of speed.

In web development,  if the developer uses the framework without grasping the whole picture and runs into unexpected issues along the way, they have to make big detours to gain knowledge.
This problem Is frequently occurs in the world of web development.
To avoid this, I recommend this lesson.
results.content_html:

results.content: Great course just got even better! Thank you Antonio!
